image.altText: A man wearing a suit stands in front of the Australian emblem holding  a report.

items.synopsis: These major budget measures reveal the type of plan the federal government has for Australia, writes Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: What's in the budget? Here are some of the major measures we know about

image.altText: Budget tree

items.synopsis: If the federal government's forecast is realised, Jim Chalmers would be the first treasurer to deliver a surplus since Peter Costello.

title.children: Federal budget to forecast first surplus in 15 years

image.altText: A tight shot of Jim Chalmers head, he wears a suit and red tie stands in front of a blue curtain

items.synopsis: When Jim Chalmers outlines his bold plan it will fire a debate about whether we are providing a cure for the nation's ills or merely kicking the can down the road, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: Will the federal budget's relief package solve a problem or ignore it?

image.altText: A composite of Mariah Carey smiling and Jason Alexander smiling.

items.synopsis: For a generation of people in both Australia and the US, the name Jenny Craig was synonymous with weight loss. But now it's closing shop in the US as some experts fear where diet culture is headed from here.

title.children: 'I feel guilty about the message I put out': The rise and fall of Jenny Craig's US weight loss empire

image.altText: Black and white photo of Victoria Cafasso wearing a striped Donald and Daisy Duck top.

items.synopsis: New forensic technology will be used to re-examine all Tasmanian cold cases, with police hoping it could finally provide answers to families and loved ones of those like Victoria, whose killer has never been found.

title.children: Police hope new technology could finally provide answers for families like Victoria's

image.altText: A woman points her finger.

items.synopsis: With an expected $4 billion budget surplus, the government comes under fire from Tasmanian senator Jacqui Lambie for withholding spending on Australia's most vulnerable.

title.children: 'Done nothing': Lambie attacks government ahead of expected budget surplus

image.altText: Man with Ukraine flag patch on uniform in foreground with damaged apartment building in background

items.synopsis: Russia fires 60 Iranian-made kamikaze drones, including 36 at Kyiv — all of which are shot down — as the Kremlin enacts a major security clampdown ahead of annual May 9 Victory Day celebrations.

title.children: Russia launches swarm of kamikaze drones at Ukraine, cancels some annual Victory Day parades

image.altText: Valery Gerasimov sits at a desk wearing military uniform.

items.synopsis: In authoritarian regimes, competent soldiers are less important than loyal ones. And, as Russia's General Valery Gerasimov may find out in the future, they also make excellent scapegoats for tyrants wishing to save their own skin, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Why this Russian general may be Ukraine's greatest asset

image.altText: You view rectilinear windows with red borders across three storeys on a modernist public housing tower.

items.synopsis: Residents of public housing towers in Flemington and North Melbourne launched a class action against the government over the sudden lockdown in July 2020.

title.children: Victorian government offers $5 million settlement over housing tower COVID-19 lockdown

image.altText: Sharks under a boat.

items.synopsis: Fishers say they're losing more and more fish to sharks. While some are calling for increased fishing quotas or culls, researchers say there's no simple answer.

title.children: Australia has one of the world’s strictest shark fisheries. But anglers say shark numbers are out of control

image.altText: A close-up of the Qantas logo on the tail of one of its planes. The sky behind it is clear.

items.synopsis: The long-running battle between Qantas and the Transport Workers' Union over the sacking of 1,700 ground staff at the height of the pandemic moves to the High Court in Canberra.

title.children: High Court to hear battle between Qantas and Transport Workers' Union over ground crew outsourcing

image.altText: Michael matthews celebrates with his arms outstretches

items.synopsis: Michael Matthews earns his first race win since the 2022 Tour de France with a dominant uphill sprint, beating fellow Australian Kaden Groves back into third place at the Giro d'Italia.

title.children: Matthews claims Giro sprint win after 'rollercoaster' season

image.altText: Two people wearing full body protective suits cross a road carrying yellow garbage bags

items.synopsis: Experts believe knowledge sharing and collaboration between countries and research organisations are the best ways to prevent the outbreak of future pandemics.

title.children: Ancient bacteria immune to antibiotics have been found in the Arctic. Can we protect ourselves if they spread?

image.altText: A girl standing next to a car.

items.synopsis: Child safety departments knowingly leave some children with carers who have had serious concerns raised about them, insiders say. In some states, foster and kinship carers don't even have a working with children check.

title.children: Alyssa grew up in an affluent suburb. She knows people don't see what's 'behind closed doors'

image.altText: The ASX close to steady in early trade as seen on the exchange's board at its Sydney office

items.synopsis: US stocks end little changed ahead of inflation data and disappointing profit results. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Wall Street mixed ahead of US inflation data, ASX set to edge lower ahead of federal budget

schema.headline: Live: Wall Street mixed ahead of US inflation data, ASX set to edge lower ahead of federal budget

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Budget expected to deliver a small surplus
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: As I mentioned, the federal government is forecasting a small surplus of around $4 billion for 2022-23, the first surplus in 15 years. That would be a big turnaround from the $36.9 billion deficit forecast in October. However, more deficits are predicted in coming years amid rising welfare costs, debt interest payments, and increased costs from the National Disability Insurance Scheme, aged care, health, and defence. My colleague N icole Hegarty takes a look:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What's in the budget?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Federal treasurer Jim Chalmers is expected to unveil a small surplus of $4 billion this financial year, the first surplus in 15 years, thanks to higher commodity prices. Other measures we know about include: $14.6 billion in cost of living relief Cheaper medicines JobSeeker payment increase expected New agency to make Australia a "renewable energy superpower" $11.3 billion to fund a 15 per cent rise for aged care workers $737 million to reduce vaping and smoking My colleague Gareth Hutchens takes a look at some of the major measures we know about:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: US stocks take a breather, ASX SPI 200 slightly lower
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Good morning, welcome to the ABC's Markets Blog. I'm Sue Lannin. Wall Street was lacklustre overnight after Friday's stellar performance thanks to a fall in the US unemployment rate, and Apple's better than expected quarterly earnings. Disappointing company profit reports weighed on the market with drug manufacturer Catalent (-25.7 per cent) tanking after warning of a $US400 million cut to its annual revenue and profit forecasts. Meanwhile, Tyson Foods slumped (-16.4 per cent) after making a loss over the second quarter. The Dow Jones index fell 0.2 per cent, the S & P 500 was flat, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.2 per cent. And as Australian investors await tonight's federal budget, the ASX SPI 200 is down 0.1 per cent, indicating a slow start for the local share market. So join me today for all the markets news.

liveBlogStreamPrepared.name: Live: Wall Street mixed ahead of US inflation data, ASX set to edge lower ahead of federal budget

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ASX SPI 200: down 0.1% to 7,263 Australian dollar: down 0.1% to 67.77 US cents Dow Jones: down 0.2% to 33,619 S & P 500: flat at 4,138 Nasdaq Composite: up 0.2% to 12,257 FTSE: up 1% to 7,778 DAX: down 0.05% to 15,953 CAC 40: up 0.1% to 7,441 Spot gold: up 0.24% to $US2,021,39 Brent crude: up 1.8% to $US76.62 a barrel Bitcoin: down 0.2% to $US27,490
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Markets snapshot at 7:25am AEST

children.content: ASX SPI 200: down 0.1% to 7,263
Australian dollar: down 0.1% to 67.77 US cents
Dow Jones:
S
P 500: flat at 4,138

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As I mentioned, the federal government is forecasting a small surplus of around $4 billion for 2022-23, the first surplus in 15 years. That would be a big turnaround from the $36.9 billion deficit forecast in October. However, more deficits are predicted in coming years amid rising welfare costs, debt interest payments, and increased costs from the National Disability Insurance Scheme, aged care, health, and defence. My colleague N icole Hegarty takes a look:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Budget expected to deliver a small surplus

featuredLink.title: Federal budget to forecast first surplus in 15 years

children.content: As I mentioned, the federal government is forecasting a small surplus of around $4 billion for 2022-23, the first surplus in 15 years.
That would be a big turnaround from the $36.9 billion deficit forecast in October.

However, more deficits are predicted in coming years amid rising welfare costs, debt interest payments, and increased costs from the National Disability Insurance Scheme, aged care, health, and defence.
My colleague N
icole Hegarty
takes a look:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Federal treasurer Jim Chalmers is expected to unveil a small surplus of $4 billion this financial year, the first surplus in 15 years, thanks to higher commodity prices. Other measures we know about include: $14.6 billion in cost of living relief Cheaper medicines JobSeeker payment increase expected New agency to make Australia a "renewable energy superpower" $11.3 billion to fund a 15 per cent rise for aged care workers $737 million to reduce vaping and smoking My colleague Gareth Hutchens takes a look at some of the major measures we know about:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What's in the budget?

featuredLink.title: What's in the budget? Here are some of the major measures we know about

children.content: Federal treasurer Jim Chalmers is expected to unveil a small surplus of $4 billion this financial year, the first surplus in 15 years, thanks to higher commodity prices.
Other measures we know about include:
$14.6 billion in cost of living relief
Cheaper medicines
JobSeeker payment increase expected
New agency to make Australia a "renewable energy superpower"
$11.3 billion to fund a 15 per cent rise for aged care workers
$737 million to reduce vaping and smoking
My colleague
Gareth Hutchens
takes a look at some of the major measures we know about:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, welcome to the ABC's Markets Blog. I'm Sue Lannin. Wall Street was lacklustre overnight after Friday's stellar performance thanks to a fall in the US unemployment rate, and Apple's better than expected quarterly earnings. Disappointing company profit reports weighed on the market with drug manufacturer Catalent (-25.7 per cent) tanking after warning of a $US400 million cut to its annual revenue and profit forecasts. Meanwhile, Tyson Foods slumped (-16.4 per cent) after making a loss over the second quarter. The Dow Jones index fell 0.2 per cent, the S & P 500 was flat, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.2 per cent. And as Australian investors await tonight's federal budget, the ASX SPI 200 is down 0.1 per cent, indicating a slow start for the local share market. So join me today for all the markets news.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US stocks take a breather, ASX SPI 200 slightly lower

children.content: Good morning, welcome to the ABC's Markets Blog.
I'm Sue Lannin.
Wall Street was lacklustre overnight after Friday's stellar performance thanks to a fall in the US unemployment rate, and Apple's better than expected quarterly earnings.
Disappointing company profit reports weighed on the market with drug manufacturer
Catalent
(-25.7 per cent) tanking after warning of a $US400 million cut to its annual revenue and profit forecasts.
Meanwhile,
Tyson Foods
slumped (-16.4 per cent) after making a loss over the second quarter.
The Dow Jones index fell 0.2 per cent, the S
P 500 was flat, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.2 per cent.
And as Australian investors await tonight's federal budget, the ASX SPI 200 is down 0.1 per cent, indicating a slow start for the local share market.
So join me today for all the markets news.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As I mentioned, the federal government is forecasting a small surplus of around $4 billion for 2022-23, the first surplus in 15 years. That would be a big turnaround from the $36.9 billion deficit forecast in October. However, more deficits are predicted in coming years amid rising welfare costs, debt interest payments, and increased costs from the National Disability Insurance Scheme, aged care, health, and defence. My colleague N icole Hegarty takes a look:

That would be a big turnaround from the $36.9 billion deficit forecast in October.

However, more deficits are predicted in coming years amid rising welfare costs, debt interest payments, and increased costs from the National Disability Insurance Scheme, aged care, health, and defence.
My colleague N

I'm Sue Lannin.
Wall Street was lacklustre overnight after Friday's stellar performance thanks to a fall in the US unemployment rate, and Apple's better than expected quarterly earnings.
Disappointing company profit reports weighed on the market with drug manufacturer
Catalent
(-25.7 per cent) tanking after warning of a $US400 million cut to its annual revenue and profit forecasts.
Meanwhile,

So join me today for all the markets news.

image.altText: King Charles sits on a throne with his crown, orb and sceptre.

items.synopsis: King Charles has given "sincere and heartfelt" thanks to everyone involved in his coronation weekend, as Buckingham Palace releases the first official portraits of the new monarch.

title.children: Buckingham Palace releases first official portrait of King Charles

image.altText: A woman blows a young child's nose.

items.synopsis: Ash and her young daughter Clancy caught influenza after they forgot to get vaccinated last year. She never wants to experience it again. So why are so many Aussie kids not getting their flu shot?

title.children: Australia is having a bad flu season and vaccination rates are falling

image.altText: People waiting in line to view a rental property

items.synopsis: ABS data shows total approvals fell in New South Wales by 34 per cent for the first three months of this year, but hardest hit were townhouses, units and high-rises.

title.children: There are only a few new Sydney homes to rent, and the market is struggling

image.altText: A smiling woman.

items.synopsis: Marisa Batti has had dermal filler injections since she turned 18. But after filler blocked a blood vessel, she wants other people to be aware of the risks.

title.children: This popular cosmetic injection procedure is linked to 12 reports of blindness

image.altText: Trenton Hoare wears a black t-shirt and looks at the camera

items.synopsis: If you don't have a rental history it can be very hard to break into the rental market. A new program for young renters will help them get a foot in the door.

title.children: Housing affordability and no rental history is a double whammy for young people

image.altText: An aerial view of Alice Springs by night.

items.synopsis: Details of tens of millions of dollars in funding to improve safety in the embattled town, announced by the prime minister in February, will be revealed for the first time in the federal budget.

title.children: Alice Springs social woes to receive big budget spend, but $100m of promised funds still missing

image.altText: a composite image of two boys facing away from the camera. their identities cannot be made out

items.synopsis: A neighbour of two teenagers with autism found locked in a room and severely malnourished in 2020, has detailed the horrific conditions they were subjected to. WARNING: This story contains content readers may find distressing.

title.children: Neighbour tells disability royal commission of horrific conditions teen boys were held in

image.altText: A side view of a saltwater crocodile on a river bank with its eye open

items.synopsis: Employing sonars and artificial intelligence, the warning system is expected to be installed at busy boat ramps as part of a suite of measures to reduce the risk of crocodile attacks in the state.

title.children: Croc-spotting device to help keep Queenslanders safe after fatal attack

image.altText: Row of large homes along waterfront with boats moored out front

items.synopsis: Two of Queensland's most sought-after regions have an estimated 10,000 properties locked up as short-stay accommodation, but affordable housing advocates say holiday lets are not the driving force behind the rental shortage.

title.children: Why AirBNBs and short-stays don't deserve all the blame for Noosa rental shortage

image.altText: Two men with backs to the camera lean up against fence looking at cattle

items.synopsis: There's dust in the air, dirt on the boots, and the booming voices of auctioneers break through the cattle-dung-scented air, but farmers don't want to let go of saleyards despite the boom in online sales.

title.children: Social power of saleyards 'like a men's shed, but not just for men'
